prob_desc_description: Once upon a time there was only one router in the well-known company Bmail. Years went by and over time new routers were purchased. Every time they bought a new router, they connected it to one of the routers bought before it. You are given the values $$$p_i$$$ â€” the index of the router to which the $$$i$$$-th router was connected after being purchased ($$$p_i < i$$$).There are $$$n$$$ routers in Boogle in total now. Print the sequence of routers on the path from the first to the $$$n$$$-th router.
prob_desc_output_spec: Print the path from the $$$1$$$-st to the $$$n$$$-th router. It starts with $$$1$$$ and ends with $$$n$$$. All the elements in the path should be distinct.
prob_desc_input_spec: The first line contains integer number $$$n$$$ ($$$2 \le n \le 200000$$$) â€” the number of the routers. The following line contains $$$n-1$$$ integers $$$p_2, p_3, \dots, p_n$$$ ($$$1 \le p_i < i$$$), where $$$p_i$$$ is equal to index of the router to which the $$$i$$$-th was connected after purchase.
source_code:
a=int(input())
c=[]
h = raw_input()
b=(list(map(int,(h.split(' ')))))
k=a-2
c.append(a)
i=1
while k>=0:
    c.append(b[k])
    k=c[i]-2
    i=i+1
c.reverse()
m=len(c)
for i in range (m):
    print c[i]
